content:
While there isn't any concrete evidence to suggest that prehistoric humans created cave paintings for practical purposes, there are a few theories that have been proposed.

One theory is that the paintings may have had some kind of instructional or educational purpose. For example, they may have been used to teach young hunters about different animal species and their behaviors, or to show travelers how to navigate through different environments.

Another theory is that the paintings may have been intended to convey information about the state of the environment, such as the location of a nearby water source or the migration patterns of certain animal species. Prehistoric humans may have used the paintings to communicate important information with each other, similar to how modern humans use signs and symbols to convey messages.

Overall, while it is possible that prehistoric cave paintings had practical uses, there is still much debate and speculation about the true purpose of these intricate artworks.
